bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Pedro Nogueira, November 10, 1952

div1.p: Hench is pleased to hear that Cooke and Hanberry will receive the Order of Finlay and suggests that Truby and Reed's son might be considered for the honor as well. He promises to provide Nogueira with a Spanish translation of his speech.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Pedro Nogueira, November 10, 1952
div1.opener:
November 10, 1952
Dr. Pedro Nogueira
Marti 219, Marianao
Havana, Cuba
My dear Pedro:
div1.p:
I received your letter of November 7 within the hour and am answering it
promptly. I believe I sent you Mrs. Cooke's name and address. I think it
would be very fine if he and Hanberry received the Finlay Order. I am
writing Hanberry today, not mentioning the Finlay Order of course, but telling
him that he will be hearing from you shortly and that he should be making
plans to go to Cuba.

I am happy to know that some of the invitations have already gone out. If
they are printed, I would like to have one very much as a souvenir to keep
with my papers, in addition to the full program which you expect to send me
shortly. I am desperately trying to finish a chapter on the use of cortizone
and ACTH in rheumatic diseases, which was due the first of November, so that
I have written nothing yet on my little talk for Havana; however I have been
thinking it over in my mind and if I don't send you ahead of time the copies
you request, I will arrive with several copies of a Spanish translation all
ready for you as I will have it done here by our Spanish interpreters.

It will be nice if the President of the Republic can be present on the occasion.
That will add great distinction. I remember many years ago being presented to
him briefly when he was inspecting a new hospital. My Cuban host told him of
my interest in Camp Lazear and Mr. Batista said that when the plans were completed
he would like to be present on the occasion. That was when he was president
before, about 1940 I believe. If you wish to remind him of his “promise” to
me, please do so.
I shall be delighted to have a few extra programs to send to interested friends.

Dr. Ames' widow is Mrs. Jessie Daniel Ames, Wrens Nest, Tryon, North Carolina.
I am not sure how much of a family they had.

I do hope that the appropriate committee considers worthy for the Finlay decora-
tion at least a few of the others that were mentioned, especially General Truby
and perhaps General Reed.

I am very happy that the Sternberg book finally arrived. I cannot understand
what held it up. I had sent a tracer on it. Yes, I have the other Sternberg
book, also the Gorgas book but I will bring them with me.
div1.closer: Always sincerely, P. S. Hench, M.D. PSH:alc
